header: Christian tells to the girls more

Helen: Hi, Judy, Cassandra. Go ahead and take your seats, please.

Cassandra: Hi, Helen. Nice to meet you!

Judy: Hi, Helen.

Author's words: Judy and Cassandra are coming in the court and sitting in the lounge.

Judy: I am always glad to be your host, Helen, because we are true friends. But I see you are looking a bit sullen. What's happened?

Helen: I think about the story Beatrix told us last time when we talked threesome: you, me and her. The story was shril.

Judy: This little flying shorty again! Do you mind that there are many other grander things in the world?

Helen: Of course, but I am not indifferent to such attractive and good creature.

Cassandra: What kind of story it was?

Helen: Last time when Judy visited me and you was busy with your work Beatrix told us her lamentable story. It was about her provenance. Earlier she was a human. There was one tragical event in result of which her life was ceased prematurely. What we see now is her epitome into this body of a decomposer after her human life.

Cassandra: Yes, it is impressive. What was the reason of her death?

Helen: Her organism was very defective because her parents were alcoholics. She does not know concretely what illness she had.

Cassandra: It is a pity that she had tragic end, died in earlier age. How is Beatrix now at all? Does she abide her security measures? Does she not breach from your aquarium without your overseeing?

Helen: No, she was very resigned and obedient last time. Now she has left me and flew from me to the nature.

Cassandra: It is definitely.

Helen: I know. It is a lamentable case that she can not go to the holidays with us. I would wish her long and happy life in this epitome.

Cassandra: I would like you to tell me how you and Judy spend your free time without me. You and Judy are more free than me now. I know you may see each other almost every day now. In the same time I am not such free as you. I continue working as a photographer.

Helen: Often we play tennis and engage some sport exercises. Also we sit here and talk about something what is related to our friendship. It is approximately like we have time all three: me, you and Judy.

Judy: Yes, it does not different from time when we are all three in our meeting.

Helen: Christian will be here with us soon. He promised to be with us for some time and communicate with us.

Cassandra: Are you serious? It seemed his work was so ongoing!

Helen: I am serious, trust me. He works very obstinately and rigorously, but sometimes he needs pauses and rest from his working. Now he has some free time to be with us or speak with his relatives.

Cassandra: It is cool! When he's going to arrive?

Helen: He will arrive soon in a little time.

Cassandra: Will we may inquire about his purposes which he is striving for?

Helen: I think, we will. I hope you can inquire about that and get answers to the questions.

Judy: I am interested in the story particularly.

Cassandra: I am, too.

Judy: Helen, do you know what statements to achieve his purposes and end were in his previous life?

Helen: I do not know that in particular. I talk with him not very often. He is always fraught with his work as I told you.

Cassandra: It is enough intriguingly for me. I believe he will cope with achieving the purposes he has determined in this life, but I am heavy waiting when he will do that!

Helen: I am concerned in successful outcome in his engagement, too. My opinion is that scientists merit to be successful and happy in their life.

Judy: As I remember we have not glided anything what relates to our holidays yet. May we switch the theme of our conversation?

Helen: Yes, of course, but when Christian arrives we be compelled to set aside the conversation on this theme. Christian intends to devote this time to us with such hopeless that this time will be suitable to be spent for inquiring all about what interests us in his job. He has not too much free time for abstraction from his job and we must devote this time to what he is being diverted for.

Judy: Of course. What shall we do else? But I want us to tell about our holidays while he is not with us. So there is an actual and pertinent question what time will he arrive.

Helen: He said he would arrive between 12 and 1.

Judy: It is expressly. Now let's talk about our time in Miami. I am imagining it in bright paints! Besides we must plan where we will live in this time.

Helen: I saw the magazine where it is told about the places where incoming visitors may live. I know you saw the magazine. But we have not made our choice yet.

Judy: Bring the magazine here, please! I will choose the place on the bank of the sea with enjoying!

Author's words: Helen is going for the magazine

Judy: You know, Cassandra, now my paramount interesting thought is about our time in the holidays! It is even more intriguingly that Christian's life albeit I am concerned about his success in the science.

Cassandra: I am interested in both these deals.

Judy: I hope the events and impressions from the holidays will divert Helen from incisive thoughts about Beatrix's flying off.

Author's words: Helen is appearing with the magazine and sitting to the table with Judy and Cassandra. Judy is taking the magazine.

Judy: It is a wonderful magazine! I see there is a map with hotels besides the images with what is in the hotel rooms! Now let's choice a haven.

Author's words: After completed choice they listed a door call.

Helen: I will open the door. I presume this is Christian.

Cassandra: If this is him it is a very opportune moment!

Helen: Who is this?

Christian: This is me, Christian.
Hi, girls.

Helen & Judy & Cassandra: Hi, Christian! Nice to meet you!

Christian: How are you?

Judy: We are going to go to the holidays in Miami. We will lay on the beach and swim in water. Also we will attend in a game museum where we will play one enthralling a bit dizzying game.

Christian: What kind of the game will it be?

Judy: It will be one game venue of which will be in water in enormous gigantic aquarium. We will be entitled play it there in special watertight suits with diving masks.

Christian: It is interesting.

Helen: Cassandra was concerned to you to go with us.

Christian: Sorry, I can not.

Helen: Can you tell us something about what you are devising now?

Christian: Of course, I can. It is not my secret.

Cassandra: What is your incentive to engage science so much?

Christian: In my previous life I did not finish anything what I was must finish. All the scientists are fond with their job very much. I am not an exception. There are no exceptions among the scientists. So I intend to do that in this life.

Cassandra: I know. I listened about that from Helen. What is it if to tell more concrete? Was there something unfathomable in your previous life to be a successful scientist?

Christian: I had so immense inclination as in this life. I conducted inquiries in such scientific area as decomposers. There was one unfavorable case in my job. At one moment I collided with one understandable fact. One day I meet a very strange looking creature in a forest.

Cassandra: Was this what really played out such negative role?

Christian: Yes, it was. I began my inquiry, but I had not could cope with my destination. It was too featured. It was something unimaginably striking. But I have not concluded that it is something superfluous and I purport to find out this secret in my current life. I know now epoch has changed. Such phenomena as extra-decomposers are norm in our epoch unlike the epoch when I lived my in previous life. So I am not thought as about a crazy man.

Cassandra: Can you tell us in particular what it was that you could not cope with in your previous life?

Christian: It is a story which will seem enough shril for human perception, but I see you are enough interested. I collided with some special entities when I learnt extra-decomposers. I was a bit shocked but not deeply. The creature looked very surprising. It was just striking! It was like a daemon. It had bright-red eyes glowing in the dark, long clutches and hissed at me!

Cassandra: It must be you were daunted very much.

Christian: I scarcely did not go mad when I saw it. I turned and run away hastily from the forest. It played out very negative role in my life. I told different people about this accident. I could not hold it in my secret. The words about this scene breached textually from me. People decided that I was crazy. So I lost right to engage science after that. I was confined in a madhouse where I died prematurely from heavy yearning by such reason as science shortage.

Judy: Yes, Christian, you were right. The story is shril really. It is unfair that some unknown creatures hinder to success in a scientist's life and lead them to lamentable end.

Christian: So as you know my possibility to continue engaging in science area was reinstated when I had been born in this life and become 3 years old.

Helen: What creature was that?

Christian: In this time we know about such creatures almost nothing. Now they are thought as about real creatures which exist not only in imagination of a crazy person, they also exist outwards of a crazy person's imagination in real world, but we know that they are somebody like daemons. Now I am working not in night time when it is not so scary.

Judy: It must be you long for to reach and find out it in this your life?

Christian: Of course, I do. I like pondering nature laws and make new discoveries and improve opened discoveries. Science engagement is an inalienable part of my life. I have epitomized in this my life exactly for this purpose. I just the same can not have this life without it. So I downright do not want be a usual child.

Judy: Is your work successfull now?

Christian: I evaluate my engagement as successful and meaningful work. Sometimes I am impelled to exert my mental forces and rack my brains in sciences, but I like it. It is so mysteriously and as if it is enchantingly. But I have not only good news. There are some hurdles to the success performing my mission. I do not like people who are hectic to believe in some unusual phenomena. For example, my granny who is enough incisive person in my life. Sometimes she impedes me to work with her hectic unrests.

Cassandra: What does she do what impedes you?

Christian: She behaves like a crazy superannuated idiot. She almost hectically philosophizes that I am a supernatural human and it is not normal. I am fed with her emotional trepidation and I do not know how to placate her mood. She scarcely is not going mad. Sometimes it summons resentment in me. It boils down that sometimes she hampers my working process and also I hinder calm in her life.

Helen: She does not look like a superannuated person. I think she is not 60 years old yet.

Christian: I am lucky my grandpa does not rage like her, but to be frankly it is amazing for me that he is calm though.

Cassandra: Is she hectic by the reason referred to the discrepancy between your age and character, attitude and capacity?

Christian: Of course, it is the reason for such mood. What else could it be?

Judy: Yes, Christian, you are a striking person! You are innovation as an extra-ordinary child, but I listened about some other children like you.

Christian: I understand you.

Judy: I listened about dissemination of such specific children as you, Christian. I read about them in papers. There are many children who have such innate aptitudes as you and are entitled to work as scientists in so early age. Did you hear about it?

Christian: Yes, I read in papers. These children have stories like mine. So now I am not the one such child in the world.

Cassandra: I found it is great!

Helen: How are your parents?

Christian: My mummy is in New York as I told you.

Helen: What about your dad? Is he OK? What is he ill?

Christian: He has gotten a venereal disease. I do not know exactly what disease is this.

Helen: Is he still in the hospital?

Christian: Yes, he is.

Helen: From whom has he been infected?

Christian: I do not know this. My dad is not very intelligent person. Rather he is an ignoramus who is interested in walking with different girls most of all. So he has walked my appearing in the world. I am glad I have gotten not very much hereditary from him.

Judy: Does your dad think about his paternity?

Christian: I think it does not bother him very much.

Cassandra: It is other horrible fact.

Christian: You know what I purport in this my life. I am a connoisseur of nature sciences and it is the most important for me. Who are my parents is not so matter.

Helen: We worry about you.

Christian: Thank you. But do not worry too much. Anything will be OK with my discretion. Excuse me, I can not linger, because my job is waiting me. It is very important. So I have to go and continue my engagement.

Cassandra: Is this all your free time for spending it with us?

Christian: Understand me, please. Now I am fraught with my work, but today I decided to make an intermission and meet you just for a little while, because I saw you and spoke with you long ago. May I go?

Helen: Of course. Thank you for time spending and communication with us. We wish you good luck in your job.

Christian: Thank you! I also wish good luck to all of you.
